results.title: Music in the wind
results.creator_credit: Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Canada carries on”.
This film traces the history of organ building through the centuries from the ancient instruments worked by foot-pump and hand bellows to the latest electrically operated giant pipe organs. Shows the building of organs in the workshops of Casavant Freres, St Hyacinthe, Quebec.

results.title: In search of home
results.creator_credit: Roger Blais, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Canada carries on”.
A film on child adoption describing how a welfare agency seeks to find the right home for each child placed under its care. How the agency goes about selecting good “parent material” is seen as two childless couples apply for adoption of a child. The first couple demonstrates the type of parental qualities looked for; in the case of the second, there is reason to doubt their ability to provide a healthy emotional environment for an adopted child. We see, too, the need for patient understanding of the delays and complications of placing the right child in the right home.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roger Blais, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada

A contrast between the sedate Toronto, Canada, of half a century ago and the thriving, expanding metropolis of today

results.title: Tomorrow's citizens
results.creator_credit: Gordon Weisenborn, Stuart Legg and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Canada carries on”
This film examines contemporary educational methods and policies in the light of an age that has released new natural energies, to be used for or against mankind. It reiterates the question sociologists ask: is the development of social responsibility in today’s children keeping pace with their technical knowledge?

results.title: Penitentiary
results.creator_credit: Ronald Weyman, Sydney Newman and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Canada carries on”.
A report on life and conditions in one of Canada’s penal institutions, illustrating current trends in the treatment of criminals. Defiant and contemptuous of society, a young first offender is brought to a federal penitentiary. The film shows the descipline, the confinement and the rigid routines which are part of a prisoner’s expiation for crime. It also deals with the challenge, now recognized by penitentiary authorities - either to change the prisoner into a law-abiding citizen or to have them come back a repeater - and with the new psychological approach which endeavours to determine the basic causes of a person’s wrong-doing.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ronald Weyman, Sydney Newman and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Gold
results.creator_credit: Colin Low, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Canada carries on”.
A description of placer gold mining in the Yukon. East of Dawson City giant dredges cut deep into the creek beds, leaving behind monstrous coils of waste as the gold-bearing gravel is washed. The film shows how gold is trapped and hand-sorted, finally to emerge as precious gold brick.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin Low, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Eyes on Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Canada carries on”.
This discussion of Canada’s international relations looks at the role of industry and agriculture in foreign trade. Canada’s effect on world affairs and the balance of power is also considered.

results.title: Arctic jungle
results.creator_credit: Sydney Newman and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Canada carries on”.
The life of the Eskimo is a constant struggle for existence against the harshness of the Arctic environment. The film shows spear fishing, making lamp fuel, manufacturing clothing and kayaks, and hunting powerful quarry like the polar bear and white whale.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sydney Newman and National Film Board of Canada
